hints.content: A diagram of the product mixture should correctly represent the product molecules as well as any unreacted reactant molecules. It should also correctly represent conservation of mass, which means that it should contain the same number and types of atoms as the diagram of the reactant mixture.

First, let’s consider the product molecules. According to the text, $\ce{H2}(g)$ reacts with $\ce{N2}(g)$ to form $\ce{NH3}(g)$. So, the diagram of the product mixture should contain representations of $\ce{NH3}$ molecules:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/3a93ef9b8ada2d2459af7958a8b886ae4aac75ed.svg)

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A molecule is represented by a central larger shaded circle surrounded by three small white circles adhering to it.

hints.content: Next, let’s think about mass conservation. The diagram of the reactant mixture contains $4$ $\ce{N}$ atoms and $14$ $\ce{H}$ atoms. So, the diagram of the product mixture should *also* contain $4$ $\ce{N}$ atoms and $14$ $\ce{H}$ atoms. All $4$ of the $\ce{N}$ atoms and $12$ of the $\ce{H}$ atoms will be present in $4$ molecules of $\ce{NH3}$, while the remaining $2$ $\ce{H}$ atoms will be present in an unreacted molecule of $\ce{H2}$.

So, the diagram that best represents the mixture after the gases have reacted is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square that has 5 molecules scattered all over the square with a large distance between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central big shaded circle and three small white circles adhering to it. The fifth molecule is two small white circles adhering to each other.

question.content:
Under certain conditions, $\ce{H2}(g)$ reacts with $\ce{N2}(g)$ to form $\ce{NH3}(g)$. A vessel contains a mixture of $\ce{H2}(g)$ and $\ce{N2}(g)$, as shown below.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the mixture after the gases have reacted as completely as possible?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt:
A big square containing a mixture of two different types of molecules and another smaller square showing the key. The big square contains 9 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Seven of the molecules are similar, each is represented by two small white circles adhering to each other. The other 2 molecules are similar, each is represented by bigger two shaded circles adhering together. 
The key square shows that each white small circle = H atom and each shaded circle = N atom.

choices.content: ![A square that has 5 molecules scattered all over the square with a large distance between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central big shaded circle and three small white circles adhering to it. The fifth molecule is two small white circles adhering to each other.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/aeee4eadf88abe7d2d814a51dd52d9203efbdb7e.svg)

![A square that has 4 molecules scattered all over the square with a large distance between them. Each is represented by a central big shaded circle and three small white circles adhering to it. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/e7d2d2c96eca28fb75a1d8c5885302957659ae8f.svg)

![A square that has 5 molecules scattered all over the square with a large distance between them. Two of the molecules are similar, each is represented by two central big shaded circle and two small white circles adhering to them from both sides. The other three molecule are similar, each is represented by two small white circles adhering to each other.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/1a10520cbfbd9b86670882d62db4903abd77bb29.svg)

hints.content: A diagram of the product mixture should correctly represent the product molecules as well as any unreacted reactant molecules. It should also correctly represent conservation of mass, which means that it should contain the same number and types of atoms as the diagram of the reactant mixture.

First, let’s consider the product molecules. According to the text, $\ce{SO2}(g)$ reacts with $\ce{O2}(g)$ to form $\ce{SO3}(g)$. So, the diagram of the product mixture should contain representations of $\ce{SO3}(g)$ molecules:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A molecule is represented by a central bigger white circle adhering to three shaded smaller circles.

hints.content: Next, let’s think about mass conservation. The diagram of the reactant mixture contains $4$ $\ce{S}$ atoms and $14$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. So, the diagram of the product mixture should *also* contain $4$ $\ce{S}$ atoms and $14$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. All $4$ of the $\ce{S}$ atoms and $12$ of the $\ce{O}$ atoms will be present in $4$ molecules of $\ce{SO3}$, while the remaining $2$ $\ce{O}$ atoms will be present in an unreacted molecule of $\ce{O2}$.

So, the diagram that best represents the mixture after the gases have reacted is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square has 5 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central larger white circle surrounded by three smaller shaded circles adhering to it. The last molecule is two small shaded circles adhering to each other.

question.content:
Under certain conditions, $\ce{SO2}(g)$ reacts with $\ce{O2}(g)$ to form $\ce{SO3}(g)$. A vessel contains a mixture of $\ce{SO2}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$, as shown below.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the mixture after the gases have reacted as completely as possible?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A square contains six molecules. Three molecules are similar; each is represented by a central big white circle and two shaded adhering small circles forming a bent shaped molecule. The other three molecules are similar; each is represented by two adhering shaded smaller circles. The molecules are scattered all over the squares with large distances between them. A key shows that each big white circle = an S atom and each small shaded circle = one O atom.

choices.content: ![A square has 5 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central larger white circle surrounded by three smaller shaded circles adhering to it. The last molecule is two small shaded circles adhering to each other.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/25a3651a35f366ed9e39d2cdfc4ac96600ee35c2.svg)

![A square has 4 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Each is represented by a central larger white circle surrounded by three smaller shaded circles adhering to it. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/551e1960c42b97eec5243c4b509b842c2fd27876.svg)

![A square has 9 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Five of the molecules are similar, each is represented by two shaded circles adhering to each other. hints.content: A diagram of the product mixture should correctly represent the product molecules as well as any unreacted reactant molecules. It should also correctly represent conservation of mass, which means that it should contain the same number and types of atoms as the diagram of the reactant mixture.

First, let’s consider the product molecules. According to the text, $\ce{H2}(g)$ reacts with $\ce{O2}(g)$ to form $\ce{H2O}(g)$. So, the diagram of the product mixture should contain representations of $\ce{H2O}$ molecules:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A molecule is formed of a central big shaded circle and two small white circles adhering to the shaded circle making a bent shaped molecule.

hints.content: Next, let’s think about mass conservation. The diagram of the reactant mixture contains $8$ $\ce{H}$ atoms and $6$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. So, the diagram of the product mixture should *also* contain $8$ $\ce{H}$ atoms and $6$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. All $8$ of the $\ce{H}$ atoms and $4$ of the $\ce{O}$ atoms will be present in $4$ molecules of $\ce{H2O}$, while the remaining $2$ $\ce{O}$ atoms will be present in an unreacted molecule of $\ce{O2}$.

So, the diagram that best represents the mixture after the gases have reacted is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square that has 5 molecules scattered all over the square with a large distance between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central big shaded circle and two small white circles adhering to it making a bent shaped molecule. The fifth molecule is two shaded big circles adhering together.

question.content:
Under certain conditions, $\ce{H2}(g)$ reacts with $\ce{O2}(g)$ to form $\ce{H2O}(g)$. A vessel contains a mixture of $\ce{H2}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$, as shown below.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the mixture after the gases have reacted as completely as possible?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A square contains three molecules of hydrogen each represented by two white adhering small circles. In addition there are three molecules of oxygen, each is represented by two adhering shaded bigger circles. The molecules are scattered all over the squares with large distances between them. Next to the square is a key to the identity of the reacting molecules and shows that each small white circle = an H atom and each big shaded circle = an O atom.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/7e9de891b2b36d89ffdd146694bae4d3ace32d9d.svg)

hints.content: A diagram of the reactant mixture should correctly represent the reactant molecules. It should also correctly represent conservation of mass, which means that it should contain the same number and types of atoms as the diagram of the product mixture.

First, let’s consider the reactant molecules. According to the information in the question, the reactant mixture contains $\ce{CH4}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$. So, the diagram of the reactant mixture should contain representations of $\ce{CH4}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/b6e35a1a248e2a224e70aa9392c1ecdb229b3b72.svg)

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two labeled molecules. The first is represented by a central black atom surrounded by four small white circles adhering to it from four sides and labeled C H 4. The second molecule is two shaded circles adhering to each other and labeled as O 2.

hints.content: Next, let’s think about mass conservation. The diagram of the product mixture contains $8$ $\ce{H}$ atoms, $2$ $\ce{C}$ atoms, and $8$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. So, the diagram of the reactant mixture should *also* contain $8$ $\ce{H}$ atoms, $2$ $\ce{C}$ atoms, and $8$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. All of these atoms will be present in either $\ce{CH4}$ or $\ce{O2}$ molecules.

So, the diagram that best represents the reactant mixture is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square contains 6 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar and each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together. The other two molecules are similar and each is represented by a central black circle surrounded by four small white circles adhering to it.

question.content:
$\ce{CH4}(g) + \ce{2O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{CO2}(g) + \ce{2H2O}(g)$

A mixture of $\ce{CH4}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ is placed in a container, and a reaction occurs according to the equation above. A particle-level representation of the product mixture at the completion of the reaction is shown below.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the reactant mixture of $\ce{CH4}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ that would yield the product mixture shown above?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A square contains four molecules; each represented by a central shaded bigger circle with two white smaller circles adhering to it making a bent shaped molecule. There are two additional molecules; each is represented by a central black circle with two shaded circles adhering to it from both sides making a chain shaped molecule. The molecules are scattered all over the squares with large distances between them. A key shows that each small white circle =  an H atom, each black circle = a C atom, and each big shaded circle = One O atom.

choices.content: ![A square contains 6 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar and each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together. The other two molecules are similar and each is represented by a central black circle surrounded by four small white circles adhering to it.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/e4b9131af0fce55dd237f9812ad85a6a8f3d75fe.svg)

![A square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar and each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together. The other four molecules are similar and each is represented by a central black circle surrounded by four small white circles adhering to it.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/7a54f583160995d452e9ebb54a94bb1dd58cd1fc.svg)

![A square contains 9 molecules scattered all over the square with large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar and each is represented by two shaded circles adhering to each other. The other four molecules are similar and each is represented by two small white circles adhering to each other. The last molecule is represented by two black circles adhering to each other.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/3b4580da96a39149d297d09ba7cda6f0fa4e26cc.svg)

![A square contains 2 molecules and 8 atoms scattered all over the square with large distances between them. The two molecules are similar and each is represented by a central black circle surrounded by four small white circles adhering to it. The 8 atoms are represented by 8 separate shaded circles.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/0301c7b428f7686eb9cd33ef9ab2ba6eadc40e19.svg)

hints.content: A diagram of the reactant mixture should correctly represent the reactant molecules. It should also correctly represent conservation of mass, which means that it should contain the same number and types of atoms as the diagram of the product mixture.

First, let’s consider the reactant molecules. According to the information in the question, the reactant mixture contains $\ce{C2H4}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$. So, the diagram of the reactant mixture should contain representations of $\ce{C2H4}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two labeled molecules. The first is represented by two central black circles adhering to each other. Each black circle has two small white circles adhering to it. This is labeled C 2 H 4. The second is represented by two shaded circles adhering to each other. This is labeled as O 2.

hints.content: Next, let’s think about mass conservation. The diagram of the product mixture contains $8$ $\ce{H}$ atoms, $4$ $\ce{C}$ atoms, and $12$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. So, the diagram of the reactant mixture should *also* contain $8$ $\ce{H}$ atoms, $4$ $\ce{C}$ atoms, and $12$ $\ce{O}$ atoms. All of these atoms will be present in either $\ce{C2H4}$ or $\ce{O2}$ molecules.

So, the diagram that best represents the reactant mixture is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square and separated by large distances. Six of the molecules are similar, each is represented by two shaded circles adhering to each other. The other two molecules are similar, each is represented by two central black circles adhering to each other. Each black circle has two small white circles adhering to it.

question.content:
$\ce{C2H4}(g) + \ce{3O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2CO2}(g) + \ce{2H2O}(g)$

A mixture of $\ce{C2H4}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ is placed in a container, and a reaction occurs according to the equation above. A particle-level representation of the product mixture at the completion of the reaction is shown below.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the reactant mixture of $\ce{C2H4}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ that would yield the product mixture shown above?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt:
One big square contains a mixture of molecules and a smaller square shows the key. The big square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a black central circle with two shaded circles adhering to it from both sides forming a chain shaped molecule. The other 4 molecules are similar, each is represented by a central shaded circle with two small white circles adhering to it from both sides forming a bent shaped molecule.
The key square shows that each white circle = H atom, each black circle = C atom, and each shaded circle = O atom.

hints.content: A diagram of the reactant mixture should correctly represent the reactant molecules. It should also correctly represent conservation of mass, which means that it should contain the same number and types of atoms as the diagram of the product mixture.

First, let’s consider the reactant molecules. According to the information in the question, the reactant mixture contains $\ce{CS2}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$. So, the diagram of the reactant mixture should contain representations of $\ce{CS2}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two labeled molecules. The first is represented by a central smaller black circle with two bigger white circles adhering to it from both sides. This forms a chain shaped molecule labeled as C S 2. The second molecule is represented by two shaded atoms adhering to each other and labeled as O 2.

hints.content: Next, let’s think about mass conservation. The diagram of the product mixture contains $2$ $\ce{C}$ atoms, $12$ $\ce{O}$ atoms, and $4$ $\ce{S}$ atoms. So, the diagram of the reactant mixture should *also* contain $2$ $\ce{C}$ atoms, $12$ $\ce{O}$ atoms, and $4$ $\ce{S}$ atoms. All of these atoms will be present in either $\ce{CS2}$ or $\ce{O2}$ molecules.

So, the diagram that best represents the reactant mixture is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square and separated by large distances. Six of the molecules are similar and each is represented by two shaded circles adhering to each other.  The other two molecules are similar, each is represented by a smaller central black circle with two bigger white circles adhering to it forming a chain shaped molecule.

question.content:
$\ce{CS2}(g) + \ce{3O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{CO2}(g) + \ce{2SO2}(g)$

A mixture of $\ce{CS2}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ is placed in a container, and a reaction occurs according to the equation above. A particle-level representation of the product mixture at the completion of the reaction is shown below.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the reactant mixture of $\ce{CS2}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ that would yield the product mixture shown above?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt:
A square contains 6 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Two of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a black central circle with two shaded circles adhering to it from both sides forming a chain shaped molecule. The other 4 molecules are similar, each is represented by a central white circle with two small shaded circles adhering to it from both sides forming a bent shaped molecule.
A key shows that each black circle = C atom, each shaded circle = O atom, and each white circle = S atom.

hints.content:
To identify the correct diagram, let’s think about what will be present in the mixture after the reaction has proceeded as completely as possible. First, we know that mixing the solutions of $\ce{BaCl2}(aq)$ and $\ce{Na2CO3}(aq)$ causes a precipitate to form:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/579d4fe5c7c1ccd17ba4767c99100cd03e4d4bf7.svg)

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line that has a small shaded hill representing a pile of solid on it, labeled as Precipitate.

hints.content:
According to the balanced equation for the reaction, the identity of the precipitate is $\ce{BaCO3}(s)$:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/bfa8e57726d4c8833768a46fcfbd8cf2f9338dbf.svg)

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line that has a small shaded hill representing a pile of powder on it, labeled as Solid B a C O 3.

hints.content:
$\ce{BaCO3}(s)$ contains one $\ce{Ba^2+}$ ion for every $\ce{CO3^2-}$ ion. Since the diagrams of the reactant solutions show there are equal numbers of $\ce{Ba^2+}$ and $\ce{CO3^2-}$ ions in solution before the reaction, this means that there will not be any $\ce{Ba^2+}$ or $\ce{CO3^2-}$ ions remaining in solution after the reaction. So, the only ions that will be present in solution after the reaction are the spectator ions, $\ce{Na+}$ and $\ce{Cl-}$:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/10807e1fe3c44d9d8769f89a93edf0822c80512d.svg)

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two circles represent ions. One is a smaller circle labeled N a with a positive one charge. The other circle is bigger and labeled as C l with a negative one charge.

hints.content:
So, the diagram that best represents the mixture after the reaction is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle of the base labeled as solid B a C O 3. The rest of the square has 8 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge. The other four circles are labeled C l with negative one charge.

question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

The solutions of $\ce{BaCl2}(aq)$ and $\ce{Na2CO3}(aq)$ represented above are mixed, causing a precipitate to form. The balanced equation for the reaction is shown below.

$\ce{BaCl2}(aq) + \ce{Na2CO3}(aq) \rightarrow \ce{BaCO3}(s) + \ce{2NaCl}(aq)$

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the mixture after the reaction has proceeded as completely as possible?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: The first square is labeled B a C l 2 (aq) and contains six circles. Four of the circles are labeled as C l with a negative charge and two slightly smaller circles are labeled as B a with positive two charge. The second square is labeled as N a 2 C O 3 (aq) and has six circles. It has four smaller circles labeled as N a with a positive one charge and two circles labeled as C O 3 with a negative two charge.

choices.content: ![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle of the base labeled as solid B a C O 3. The rest of the square has 8 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge. The other four circles are labeled C l with negative one charge.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/fbf03c4748440d348924f7b310c9aee75a8a7efa.svg)

![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as solid B a C O 3. The rest of the square has 11 circles scattered all over the square. Six of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge and four circles are labeled C l with negative one charge. The last circle is labeled as C O 3 with a negative two charge.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/17f4676800ee8bf4fd8a620a8adf70ed3589b1c4.svg)

![A square contains an arrow pointing at the bottom middle of the base labeled as No solid. In the rest of the square there are 12 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge. Four circles are labeled C l with negative one charge. Two of the circles are labeled as C O 3 with a negative two charge. The last two circles are labeled B a with positive two charge.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/619fd6150acd77a5006c57012afae9cc6a8f450d.svg)

![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as solid N a C l. The rest of the square has 4 circles scattered all over the square. Two of the circles are smaller and labeled B a with a positive two charges. The other two circles are labeled as C O 3 with a negative two charges.](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/87c5a8a10170dac2673e7385ec680dc0654f1c05.svg)

hints.content:
To identify the correct diagram, let’s think about what will be present in the mixture after the reaction has proceeded as completely as possible. First, we know that mixing the solutions of $\ce{Pb(NO3)2}(aq)$ and $\ce{Na2S}(aq)$ causes a precipitate to form:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line that has a small shaded hill representing a pile of solid on it, labeled as Precipitate.

hints.content:
According to the balanced equation for the reaction, the identity of the precipitate is $\ce{PbS}(s)$:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line that has a small shaded hill representing a pile of solid on it, labeled as Solid P b S.

hints.content:
$\ce{PbS}(s)$ contains one $\ce{Pb^2+}$ ion for every $\ce{S^2-}$ ion. Since the diagrams of the reactant solutions show there are equal numbers of $\ce{Pb^2+}$ and $\ce{S^2-}$ ions in solution before the reaction, this means that there will not be any $\ce{Pb^2+}$ or $\ce{S^2-}$ ions remaining in solution after the reaction. So, the only ions that will be present in solution after the reaction are the spectator ions, $\ce{Na+}$ and $\ce{NO3-}$:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two circles represent ions. One is a smaller circle labeled N a with a positive one charge and the other circle is bigger and labeled as N O 3 with a negative one charge,

hints.content:
So, the diagram that best represents the mixture after the reaction is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as solid P b S. The rest of the square has 8 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge, and four circles are labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge.

question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

The solutions of $\ce{Pb(NO3)2}(aq)$ and $\ce{Na2S}(aq)$ represented above are mixed, causing a precipitate to form. The balanced equation for the reaction is shown below.

$\ce{Pb(NO3)2}(aq) + \ce{Na2S}(aq) \rightarrow \ce{PbS}(s) + \ce{2NaNO3}(aq)$

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the mixture after the reaction has proceeded as completely as possible?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: The first square is labeled P b ( N O 3) 2 (aq) and contains 6 circles. Four of the circles are bigger and labeled as N O 3 with a negative one charge. In addition, there are two circles labeled as P b with a positive two charge. The second square is labeled as N a 2 S (aq) and contains 6 circles. It has four smaller circles labeled as N a with a positive one charge, and two circles labeled as S with a negative two charge.

choices.content: ![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as solid P b S. The rest of the square has 8 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge, and four circles are labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/191855ed37bd25a4e711367e6bc63e53c8e3c3ef.svg)

![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as Solid P b S. The rest of the square has 11 circles scattered all over the square. Six of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge and four circles are labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge. The last circle is labeled S with negative two charges. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/259b3590473aead6a1390ccbbe258390108cc422.svg)

![A square contains an arrow pointing at the middle base labeled as No solid. The rest of the square has 12 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled N a with a positive one charge, and four circles are labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge. Two circles are labeled S with negative two charges and two circles are labeled P b with positive two charges. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/27b7311885f19bbdae35efca8a14f74b72462539.svg)

![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as Solid N a N O 3. The rest of the square has 4 circles scattered all over the square. Two circles are labeled S with negative two charges and two circles are labeled P b with positive two charges. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/b95b524bdab4b6bbaafaa6913a2731a0e66134dd.svg)

hints.content:
To identify the correct diagram, let’s think about what will be present in the mixture after the reaction has proceeded as completely as possible. First, we know that mixing the solutions of $\ce{KOH}(aq)$ and $\ce{CaCl2}(aq)$ causes a precipitate to form:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line that has a small shaded hill representing a pile of solid on it, labeled as Precipitate.

hints.content:
According to the balanced equation for the reaction, the identity of the precipitate is $\ce{Ca(OH)2}(s)$:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line that has a small shaded hill on it representing a pile of solid on it, labeled as Solid C a ( O H ) 2.

hints.content:
$\ce{Ca(OH)2}(s)$ contains one $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ion for every two $\ce{OH-}$ ions. Since the diagrams of the reactant solutions show there are half as many $\ce{Ca^2+}$ ions as $\ce{OH-}$ ions in solution before the reaction, this means that there will not be any $\ce{Ca^2+}$ or $\ce{OH-}$ ions remaining in solution after the reaction. So, the only ions that will be present in solution after the reaction are the spectator ions, $\ce{K+}$ and $\ce{Cl-}$:


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: Two circles of equal size are side by side. One circle is labeled K with a positive one charge and the other circle is labeled C l with a negative one charge.

hints.content:
So, the diagram that best represents the mixture after the reaction is


[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as Solid C a (O H) 2. The rest of the square has 8 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled K with a positive one charge and four circles are labeled C l with a negative one charge.

question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

The solutions of $\ce{KOH}(aq)$ and $\ce{CaCl2}(aq)$ represented above are mixed, causing a precipitate to form. The balanced equation for the reaction is shown below.

$\ce{2KOH}(aq) + \ce{CaCl2}(aq) \rightarrow \ce{2KCl}(aq) + \ce{Ca(OH)2}(s)$

**Which of the following diagrams best represents the mixture after the reaction has proceeded as completely as possible?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: The first square is labeled K O H (aq) and contains 8 circles.  Four of the circles are bigger and labeled as K with a positive one charge and four circles are labeled as O H with a negative one charge. The second square is labeled as C a C l 2 (aq) and has 6 circles. It has two smaller circles labeled as C a with a positive two charge and four circles labeled as C l with a negative one charge.

choices.content: ![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as Solid C a (O H) 2. The rest of the square has 8 circles scattered all over the square. Four of the circles are smaller and labeled K with a positive one charge and four circles are labeled C l with a negative one charge. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/5a5dc689a1b85cd72d0e8098ca247f659e3fa3bf.svg)

![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as Solid C a (O H) 2. The rest of the square has 10 circles scattered all over the square. ![A square contains a small shaded hill at the middle base labeled as Solid K Cl. The rest of the square has 6 circles scattered all over the square. Two of the circles are smaller and labeled C a with positive two charges and four circles are labeled O H with a negative one charge. ](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/dc1a3d23851a25e61a8609ef3771e7c760762fe4.svg)

hints.content: To determine the equation that best describes the reaction, we first need to identify the reactants and products using the diagram. Then, we can use this information to write out a balanced chemical equation for the reaction.

Let’s start by identifying the reactants and products. According to the diagram, the left box (which represents the mixture *before* the reaction) contains $\ce{CO}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules, while the right box (which represents the mixture *after* the reaction) contains $\ce{CO2}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules. Since $\ce{O2}$ molecules appear in both boxes, this tells us that the $\ce{O2}$ molecules in the right box are leftover reactant molecules. So, the reactants are $\ce{CO}$ and $\ce{O2}$, and the only product is $\ce{CO2}$.

Next, let’s write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction. We know that $\ce{CO}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ are reacting to form $\ce{CO2}(g)$. The *unbalanced* equation for this reaction is

$\ce{CO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{CO2}(g)$

We can balance the equation by putting the coefficient $2$ in front of both $\ce{CO}$ and $\ce{CO2}$:

$\ce{2CO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2CO2}(g)$

So, the equation that best describes the reaction is

* $\ce{2CO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2CO2}(g)$

question.content:
The following diagram represents a reaction between two chemical species.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following equations best describes the reaction?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt:
Two big squares are separated by an arrow with a third smaller square showing the key. The first big square contains 9 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a black circle adhering to a shaded circle. The other 5 molecules are similar, each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together. 
The second big square contains 7 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Four of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central black circle with two shaded circles adhering to it from both sides. The other three molecules are represented by two shaded circles adhering together.
The key square shows that each black circle = C atom and each shaded circle = O atom.

choices.content: $\ce{2CO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2CO2}(g)$
$\ce{CO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{CO2}(g)$
$\ce{4CO}(g) + \ce{5O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{4CO2}(g) + \ce{3O2}(g)$
$\ce{C}(g) + \ce{2O}(g) \rightarrow \ce{CO2}(g)$

hints.content: To determine the equation that best describes the reaction, we first need to identify the reactants and products using the diagram. Then, we can use this information to write out a balanced chemical equation for the reaction.

Let’s start by identifying the reactants and products. According to the diagram, the left box (which represents the mixture *before* the reaction) contains $\ce{NO}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules, while the right box (which represents the mixture *after* the reaction) contains $\ce{NO2}$ and $\ce{O2}$ molecules. Since $\ce{O2}$ molecules appear in both boxes, this tells us that the $\ce{O2}$ molecules in the right box are leftover reactant molecules. So, the reactants are $\ce{NO}$ and $\ce{O2}$, and the only product is $\ce{NO2}$.

Next, let’s write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction. We know that $\ce{NO}(g)$ and $\ce{O2}(g)$ are reacting to form $\ce{NO2}(g)$. The *unbalanced* equation for this reaction is

$\ce{NO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{NO2}(g)$

We can balance the equation by putting the coefficient $2$ in front of both $\ce{NO}$ and $\ce{NO2}$:

$\ce{2NO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2NO2}(g)$

So, the equation that best describes the reaction is

* $\ce{2NO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2NO2}(g)$

question.content:
The following diagram represents a reaction between two chemical species.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following equations best describes the reaction?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt:
Two big squares are separated by an arrow with a third smaller square showing the key. The first big square contains 11 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Six of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a white circle adhering to a shaded circle. The other 5 molecules are similar, each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together. 
The second big square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Six of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a central white circle with two shaded circles adhering to it from both sides. The other two molecules are represented by two shaded circles adhering together.
The key square shows that each white circle = N atom and each shaded circle = O atom.

choices.content: $\ce{2NO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2NO2}(g)$
$\ce{NO}(g) + \ce{O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{NO2}(g)$
$\ce{6NO}(g) + \ce{5O2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{6NO2}(g) + \ce{2O2}(g)$
$\ce{N}(g) + \ce{2O}(g) \rightarrow \ce{NO2}(g)$

hints.content: To determine the equation that best describes the reaction, we first need to identify the reactants and products using the diagram. Then, we can use this information to write out a balanced chemical equation for the reaction.

Let’s start by identifying the reactants and products. According to the diagram, the left box (which represents the mixture *before* the reaction) contains $\ce{H2}$ and $\ce{Cl2}$ molecules, while the right box (which represents the mixture *after* the reaction) contains $\ce{HCl}$ and $\ce{Cl2}$ molecules. Since $\ce{Cl2}$ molecules appear in both boxes, this tells us that the $\ce{Cl2}$ molecules in the right box are leftover reactant molecules. So, the reactants are $\ce{H2}$ and $\ce{Cl2}$, and the only product is $\ce{HCl}$.

Next, let’s write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction. We know that $\ce{H2}(g)$ and $\ce{Cl2}(g)$ are reacting to form $\ce{HCl}(g)$. The *unbalanced* equation for this reaction is

$\ce{H2}(g) + \ce{Cl2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{HCl}(g)$

We can balance the equation by putting the coefficient $2$ in front of $\ce{HCl}$:

$\ce{H2}(g) + \ce{Cl2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2HCl}(g)$

So, the equation that best describes the reaction is

* $\ce{H2}(g) + \ce{Cl2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2HCl}(g)$

question.content:
The following diagram represents a reaction between two chemical species.


[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following equations best describes the reaction?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt:
Two big squares are separated by an arrow with a third smaller square showing the key. The first big square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Three of the molecules are similar, each is represented by two smaller white circles adhering to each other. The other 5 molecules are similar, each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together.
The second big square contains 8 molecules scattered all over the square and has large distances between them. Six of the molecules are similar, each is represented by a smaller white circle adhering to a bigger shaded circle. The other two molecules are similar, each is represented by two shaded circles adhering together.
The key square shows that each white circle =  H atom and each shaded circle = C l atom.

choices.content: $\ce{H2}(g) + \ce{Cl2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{2HCl}(g)$
$\ce{H2}(g) + \ce{Cl2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{HCl}(g)$
$\ce{3H2}(g) + \ce{5Cl2}(g) \rightarrow \ce{6HCl}(g) + \ce{2Cl2}(g)$
$\ce{H}(g) + \ce{Cl}(g) \rightarrow \ce{HCl}(g)$
